'Sault Ste. Marie' ( "Soo Saint Marie") is a city on the St. Marys River in
Algoma District, Ontario, Canada. It is the third largest city in Northern
Ontario, after Sudbury and Thunder Bay. The community was founded as a French
religious mission: Sault either means "jump" [http://www.saultstemarie.org/-
index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=174&Itemid=138 Sault Ste. Marie
History] or "rapids" [http://foundlocally.com/sault/local/Info-
CityHistoryIndians.htm Local: Sault Ste. Marie History - Early
Exploration] in French, and thus the entire name translates to "Saint
Mary's Rapids" or "Saint Mary's Falls". Although the word sault is pronounced
like "so" (soÊ) in French, it is pronounced like "soo" (suË) in the English
pronunciation of the city name. Residents of the city are called Saultites. With
a mission established by French Jesuits in 1668, claiming of the area by Simon-
FranÃ§ois Daumont de Saint-Lusson, in the name of Louis XIV of France, and fur
trading posts soon after, this was one of the oldest European settlements in
Canada. [http://www.thenorthview.org/history/saultdesaintemarie.html "Sault
Ste. Marie - history"] , The North View, accessed 20 Dec 2008

Sault Ste. Marie is bordered to the east by the Rankin
categories: Populated places on the Great Lakes
headings: Alternative Energy Capital of North America
